Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Data Quality Assurance and Inventory Tool (One-Voice) for Sewer Inspection Data

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the ability to provide an easily accessible and reliable national sewer data inventory that will assist municipal utility districts in developing effective and proactive maintenance and rehabilitation plans, hence reducing the overall maintenance costs of sewer systems as well as avoiding costly repairs due to pipe failures. Moreover, if the technology is successfully commercialized, sewer officials such as National Association of Sewer Service Companies (NASSCO) will better understand the current and trend of sewer systems condition nation-wide; as such, they will have proven justification to secure adequate federal funding for sewer system improvements. This technology will support the nation's agenda of improving the condition of the aging and deteriorating sewer infrastructure, which will promote societal wellbeing and support the sustainable development of the society. In addition, it has been expected that the availability of national sewer inventory will help the industry to find new uses of sewer data and new collaborations. The participation in the NSF I-Corps program affords graduate students a great opportunity to cultivate their skills in innovation and entrepreneurship, which may lead to the creation of start-up companies and more job opportunities.

This I-Corps project addresses common concerns -- data availability and data quality -- raised by sewer industry stakeholders. Understanding the current condition and deterioration mechanism of sewer pipe networks is a critical step in improving national wastewater systems, which requires easily accessible and reliable data. Although sewer inspection data have been collected by various utility districts across the country for many years, the data is not in a usable and uniform format for asset management purposes. This technology provides a visual tool to evaluate and report data quality issues and an innovative algorithm to resolve these issues. The preliminary results show that, by applying the proposed quality assurance algorithm to six datasets obtained by the team, the percentage of good quality inspection data increased from 50%-75% (pre-process) to 95% (post-process). More importantly, the proposed technology includes a comprehensive, uniform, and quality-assured national sewer inventory that documents the historical and current conditions of sewer pipelines. Through the regional NSF I-Corps site program, it was concluded that there is a tremendous need for the proposed technology among utilities and contractors because of the time and cost savings that can be realized in inspection processes and rehabilitation plans.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
I-Corps: Data Quality Assurance and Inventory Tool (One-Voice) for Sewer Inspection Data

Award ID: 1849023

Outcome Report

 

This project provides a clear understanding of the sewer industry's needs regarding data management and evaluation that is the first step in developing asset management plans. The team has conducted over 120 interviews with sewer industry stakeholders, such as water and wastewater division managers, sewer engineers, underground consultants and contractors, sewer inspection operators, and rehabilitation contractors. Also, the feedback obtained from customer discovery helped the team better define the technology to meet those needs.

The main findings of this project are as follows:

1. This work confirms the status of the PACP (Pipeline Assessment and Certification Program) implementation in the industry. PACP has become the de facto industry standard for sewer pipes condition assessment. Municipalities are using PACP databases to make informative and prioritized maintenance decisions. The main advantage of using PACP from the perspective of data management is its consistency in data structure. However, it was recognized that while the majority of the data is collected by using the PACP standard coding system, some minor changes have been applied to the coding system, which eliminates this advantage. Also, there are still several municipalities ? mainly small-sized (less than 25,000 in population) - that cannot find value in PACP due to its expenses or are not even aware of PACP. Small-sized municipalities are more than 75% of the utilities in the US, and they can be considered as a large customer segment.

2. The quality of collected data is can be considered as one of the major obstacles to use the collected data for making informative asset management decisions in terms of maintenance and rehabilitation plans. Therefore, some municipalities have implemented QA/QC process to evaluate the quality of data manually. The team has found that these municipalities usually review 20%-100% collected data by external parties but only review 10%-30% of the inspections done by in-house personnel. Currently, it is estimated that 30% of the sewer inspection data is poor and defective.

3. Data management and utilization have been a major problem for municipalities. Although the inspection data has been collected for several years, the data is not in a usable format or readily accessible for engineering departments? use. In other words, engineers do not use real-world data to support their plans. The team found that the current inspection and data management practices can cause more than 30% data inconsistency and 50% data redundancy, which can be considered as a major source of poor data quality.

4. Currently, there is no national sewer inventory that integrates the condition data of all sewer pipes across the country. A sustainable national sewer inventory is needed because it will present empirical data that accurately demonstrates the condition and trends for underground sewer infrastructure across the United States. The research team found out that benchmarking with other utilities could be very helpful because municipalities can adopt maintenance strategies from other better performing municipalities to improve their own systems. Also, small utilities can use large municipalities? resources, which is happening in some of the municipalities in the South.

 

The broader impacts of this project are:

1. The interviews with over 120 industry experts across the country depict the clear picture of the sewer industry needs, which will guide the team to develop a prototype to properly address those needs. This tool to be developed will help those municipalities that are looking for new technologies to assess their system condition more accurately and resolve their current problems. With quality assured sewer inspection data, municipalities can develop effective and proactive maintenance plans, which can reduce the overall maintenance costs and avoid costly repairs due to pipe failure. This technology will support the nation?s agenda of improving the condition of the aging and deteriorating sewer infrastructure, which will in turn promote societal wellbeing and support the sustainable development of society.

2. This project offered great opportunities to train a graduate student in performing customer discovery based on a proof-of-concept technology. This project provided a valuable experience for the graduate student to become a more independent entrepreneurial lead, which has paved the way for the student to continue to pursue innovation in research and to transform research into technology commercialization.
